coredata.dc:title: Carbon K-edge X-ray absorption fine structures of ethylene and acetylene adsorbed onto nickel(II) surface
coredata.dc:creator: Carr, R.G.
Sham, T.K.
Eberhardt, W.E.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The carbon K-edge X-ray absorption spectra of ethylene and acetylene adsorbed on a Ni(111) surface at 300 K exhibit C(1s) to π* and σ shape-resonance transitions. The polarization dependence of the π* and σ resonances and their energies are used to infer that the adsorbed species has an unsaturated carbon-carbon bond, regardless of whether the adsorbate was C2H2 or C2H4, and that the molecular axis of the adsorped species is parallel to the surface.

The adsorption ofethylene and acetylene on Ni(lll) has been studied with low-energy electron diffraction, Auger electron spectroscopy, thermal desorption spec- troscopy, photoelectron spectroscopy, and electron energy loss spectroscopy [1 5]. These studies have provided evidence that temperature-dependent chem- ical changes occur in the adsorbate. However, the bond configuration and orientation of the adsorbate have not been explicitly determined. Here we present the results of a study ofethylene and acetylene on a ?(111) surface using near edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) This technique leveals the ener- gies of the unoccupied and partially occupied molecular orbitals below the vacuum level, and of the quasibound states (shape resonances) in the continuum. The ener- gies of these final state shape resonances has been found to be very sensitive to changes in the intemuclear distances within diatomic and polyatomic molecules of carbon, nitrogen and oxygen, both in the gas phase and when adsorbed on a metal [6 8]. A nickel(lll) crystal 1 cm in diameter was mounted on a tantalum foil for resistive heating. The absorption at about 287.5 eV, is easily identified with a carbon Is to -a* transition by comparison with gas phase spectra [10,11] - In addition, there is a broad absorption band above the v* peak, part of which is ascribed to a shape resonance due to a transition from carbon Is to a quasi-bound state of definite symmetry (<r) in the continuum. From fig. 1, we observe that the maximum absorption probability of the ar* resonance occurs for light at glancing incidence, so that the polarization vector is nearly normal to the surface of the crystal. The C Is to TT* transition is the strongest for the po- larization vector normal to the C C axis of the adsor- bate. Thus we infer that the molecular axis is approxi- mately parallel to the surface. It is interesting to compare our results to the work ofKoestner ct al. [14] for C^H^ on Pt(lll). We find the a shape resonance at a slightly higher energy (^3 eV). This would imply a shorter bond length for the C C species on Ni relative to Pt- Using a scattered wave Xa technique Horsley [15] recently showed that the NEXAFS structure cf C^ti^ adsorbed on Pt(lll) at 90 K was consistent with a di-o bonded con- figuration. It is conceivable that C^I-L adsorbed on Ni(lll) has the same configuration. Therefore a shorter C C bond on Ni(lll) seems reasonable taking ini'o account the smaller lattice spacing of Ni versus Pt- In isolated molecules, bond lengths can be success- fully derived from the position of the a shape resonan- ce [16]. However this correlation might not readily apply to chemisorbed molecules because the a shape resonance is extremely sensitive to the detailed shape of the angular momentum barrier in the final state potential as Dehmer and co-workers [17] have demon- strated Certainly this barrier is modified by the presence of the metal substrate in chemisorbed mole- cules. These changes in the final state potential depend on the adsorption configuration and might result in a shift of the a resonance energy not directly correla- ted with the change in bond length of the molecule. Therefore we feel that the effect of the change in the potential by the surface on the a shape resonance to be studied by detailed theoretical calculation before we can derive accurate bond length changes of chemi- sorbed molecules based on the energy position of the CT shape resonance. Nevertheless, semiquantitative in- formation can be obtained If we take the shape res- onance energy of 298 2 eV for the C^H^ on Ni(lll) and compare it to the results for C^I^ on Pt(l 11) [18], we derive a bond length of 1.45 0.04 A for the di-a bonded "C^" species on Ni(lll). This agrees very well with the bond length of 1.47 A determined by EELS [4]. The carbon carbon bond axis of this species is nearly parallel to the surface and the bond is unsatuiated.
